sect1.title: Saving Files
sect1.para: There are several ways to save a file that is currently open. If the file already exists, &gnum; will simply overwrite the file with the newer version. If the file is new, the first time &gnum; goes to save the file it will invoke the Save As... dialog to ask the user what to name the file and what type of file to create. This dialog can also be invoked at any time to save a new file with either a different name or of a different type.

sect1.para: When saving new files, or when saving a new copy of the current file, the File Save dialog must be used. Once a file has been created, using the methods above will only cause the saved file to be updated. The methods below will open the File Save dialog.

variablelist.title: Two alternative ways to open the File Save dialog.

listitem.para:
Type the combintation
Shift Ctrl s , typing all three keys simultaneously.

sect1.para: Both methods will launch the File Save dialog to allow the user to name the file, select a location (also called a directory or a folder) for the file and choose a file type. This dialog will also open automatically the first time a new file is saved.

sect2.title: The file formats which Gnumeric can write.
sect2.para: &gnum; can write files in several formats used by other programs. The creation of files which consist of structured text is described in . The creation of Postscript and Portable Document Format (PDF) files is done through the printing mechanism and is described in .&gnum; can also export text data or HTML and XHTML tables through the clipboard mechanism, as is explained in .

note.para: Most of these formats are provided by plugins, which are independent, configurable modules. If a format described below does not appear in the File Save dialog, this may be because the appropriate plugin has not been configured or started. This can be verified by examining the list of plugins which are currently running in the Plugin Manager dialog.

The Plugin Manager dialog lists the plugins which are currently in use and provides a way to start plugins which are currently disabled. The Plugin Manager can be started by selecting, in the Tools menu, the Plug-ins... menu item; see for more information.
